metadata.title: St. Margaret's Bay Field Guide
metadata.location: St. Margaret's Bay and Surrounding Area, Nova Scotia
metadata.description: Comprehensive field guide covering marine, freshwater, and terrestrial species. Includes game species, conservation priorities, and common identifiable species.

conservation_score_scale.description: Conservation score from 1 (critically at risk) to 10 (abundant)
conservation_score_scale.6-7: Least Concern but managed / Stable with some concerns
conservation_score_scale.source: Based on IUCN Red List, COSEWIC, and regional population data

flora.identification: Long brown ribbons up to 3 meters. Attached to rocks. Forms underwater forests.
flora.educational_value: Creates important marine habitat. Kelp forests support many species.
flora.conservation_notes: Kelp forests common. Some harvesting but populations stable.

flora.identification: Brown seaweed with air bladders that pop when squeezed. Very common on rocks.
flora.educational_value: Most abundant seaweed on rocky shores. Provides habitat.
flora.conservation_notes: Rockweed extremely abundant on rocky shores.

flora.identification: Bright green, thin as paper. Grows in sheets. Ruffled edges.
flora.educational_value: Easy to identify by bright green color. Indicator of water quality.
flora.conservation_notes: Sea lettuce very common. Can indicate nutrient pollution.

fauna.identification: Dark blue-black shells. Attached to rocks in dense clusters. Orange meat inside.
fauna.educational_value: Important commercial species. Filter feeders that clean water.
fauna.conservation_notes: Blue mussels very common. Important aquaculture species.

fauna.identification: Small spiral shell. Often in huge groups on rocks. Found between tide lines.
fauna.educational_value: Most common shore animal. Easy to find and observe.
fauna.conservation_notes: Periwinkles extremely abundant on rocky shores.

fauna.identification: Usually orange or purple. Five arms with rough bumpy skin. Can regenerate lost arms.
fauna.educational_value: Charismatic species students enjoy. Important predator of mussels.
fauna.conservation_notes: Sea stars common. Important mussel predator.

fauna.identification: Green colored shell. Aggressive behavior. Five spines on each side of shell.
fauna.educational_value: Invasive species causing ecosystem damage. Learn about harmful introductions.
fauna.conservation_notes: Invasive species. Green crab itself is abundant but threatens native species.

fauna.identification: Grey-green with white belly. Three dorsal fins. Barbel on chin.
fauna.educational_value: Historically important fishery. Now protected due to overfishing.
fauna.conservation_notes: Atlantic cod populations collapsed in 1990s. Some recovery but still vulnerable.

fauna.identification: Large claws, dark greenish-brown color. Lives in rocky crevices.
fauna.educational_value: Major commercial fishery. Learn about sustainable management.
fauna.conservation_notes: Lobster fishery well-managed with size limits, season restrictions. Populations healthy.

fauna.identification: Wide oval shell. Red spots on underside. Large claws. Hides under rocks.
fauna.educational_value: Common shore crab. Easy to find at low tide.
fauna.conservation_notes: Rock crabs common. Some fishing pressure.

fauna.identification: Black head and neck with white chinstrap. Brown body. V-formation flying. Loud honking.
fauna.educational_value: Major waterfowl hunting species. Teaches migration patterns.
fauna.conservation_notes: Canada goose populations have increased dramatically. Sometimes considered pest.

fauna.identification: Silvery with black spots. Hooked jaw in breeding males. Powerful swimmer.
fauna.educational_value: Endangered. Demonstrates anadromous migration (freshwater to ocean and back).
fauna.iucn_status: Least Concern globally, but Endangered in parts of North America
fauna.conservation_notes: Inner Bay of Fundy Atlantic Salmon are endangered. Habitat loss and dams major threats.

fauna.identification: Large rodent with flat scaly tail. Builds dams and lodges. Look for gnawed trees.
fauna.educational_value: Ecosystem engineer. Creates wetland habitat for many other species.
fauna.conservation_notes: Beaver populations recovered after historical overhunting. Now common.

fauna.identification: Males have green head, yellow bill. Females brown mottled. Found on lakes and ponds.
fauna.educational_value: Important waterfowl hunting species. Wetland indicator.
fauna.conservation_notes: Mallard populations stable. Most common duck species.

fauna.identification: Dark with light spots and wavy markings. Red and blue spots. Orange fins.
fauna.educational_value: Native game fish. Indicator of cold, clean water.
fauna.conservation_notes: Native brook trout. Sensitive to water temperature and quality.

fauna.identification: Snake-like fish with continuous fin. Dark on top, light below.
fauna.educational_value: Declining populations. Opposite migration of salmon (ocean to freshwater).
fauna.conservation_notes: Declined by 99% since 1980s. Dams, habitat loss, climate change.

flora.identification: Leaves with 3-5 pointed lobes. Winged seeds (helicopters). Brilliant fall colors.
flora.educational_value: Canadian national symbol. Source of maple syrup.
flora.conservation_notes: Maple trees very common. Important for wildlife and syrup.

flora.identification: White or yellow peeling bark. Small leaves with serrated edges. Catkins in spring.
flora.educational_value: Easily identified by distinctive bark. Important for wildlife.
flora.conservation_notes: Birch trees common. Important for wildlife.

flora.identification: Needles grow all around branch. Sharp needles. Cones hang downward. Cone scales flexible.
flora.educational_value: Nova Scotia provincial tree. Most common conifer in forests.
flora.conservation_notes: Spruce very common. Provincial tree of Nova Scotia.

flora.identification: Long needles in bundles of 2-5. Large woody cones. Straight tall trunk.
flora.educational_value: Important timber species. Easy to identify by needle bundles.
flora.conservation_notes: Pine trees common. Important timber species.

fauna.identification: Very small, about pinhead size. Eight legs. Black legs. Found in grass and brush.
fauna.educational_value: Can carry Lyme disease. Important for outdoor safety awareness.
fauna.conservation_notes: Tick populations expanding northward with climate change. Health concern.

fauna.identification: Small. Black cap and bib. White cheeks. Grey back. Call sounds like name.
fauna.educational_value: Very common at feeders. Easy to attract and observe.
fauna.conservation_notes: Chickadees very common at feeders and in forests.

fauna.identification: Bright blue above, white below. Black necklace. Crested head. Loud calls.
fauna.educational_value: Easy to identify by color. Common at bird feeders.
fauna.conservation_notes: Blue jays very common. Found in forests and urban areas.

fauna.identification: Orange wings with black veins and white spots. Large butterfly.
fauna.educational_value: Famous for long-distance migration to Mexico. Conservation concern.
fauna.conservation_notes: Monarch butterfly populations declining. Habitat loss and climate change.

fauna.identification: Fuzzy round body. Black and yellow stripes. Buzzing flight sound.
fauna.educational_value: Important pollinator. Essential for food crops and wildflowers.
fauna.conservation_notes: Some bumblebee species declining due to habitat loss and pesticides.

fauna.identification: Orange-red breast, grey-brown back. Yellow bill. Hops on ground.
fauna.educational_value: One of first birds learned. Sign of spring. Eats earthworms.
fauna.conservation_notes: American robin one of most abundant North American birds.

fauna.identification: All black plumage. Crows smaller, fan-shaped tail. Ravens larger, wedge-shaped tail.
fauna.educational_value: Very intelligent. Common everywhere. Different calls distinguish species.
fauna.conservation_notes: Crows and ravens very common. Highly intelligent and adaptable.

fauna.identification: Very large raptor. Adults have white head and tail, brown body. Large yellow hooked beak.
fauna.educational_value: National bird. Conservation success story after DDT ban.
fauna.conservation_notes: Bald eagle recovered after DDT ban. Now stable and increasing.

fauna.identification: Small, reddish-brown fur with white belly. Very active and vocal. Lives in trees.
fauna.educational_value: Very common. Easy to observe. Active during daytime.
fauna.conservation_notes: Red squirrels very common throughout Nova Scotia forests.

fauna.category: Game Species - Major hunting target in Nova Scotia
fauna.identification: Brown coat in summer, grey in winter. White tail flashes when running. Males have antlers. Look for tracks with split hooves.
fauna.educational_value: Primary game animal. Important for hunting regulations and wildlife management education.
fauna.conservation_notes: White-tailed deer abundant. Managed through hunting. Sometimes overabundant.

fauna.category: Game Species - Largest game animal in Nova Scotia
fauna.identification: Very large. Dark brown, long legs, humped shoulders. Males have large palmate antlers. Bell (skin flap) under throat.
fauna.educational_value: Major game species. Learn about moose-vehicle collisions and population management.
fauna.population_trend: Stable to increasing in some areas
fauna.conservation_notes: Hunted but populations managed. Vehicle collisions a concern.

fauna.identification: Chicken-sized bird. Fan-shaped tail with black band. Drumming sound in spring.
fauna.educational_value: Important game bird. Indicator of healthy forest habitat.
fauna.conservation_notes: Ruffed grouse populations stable. Managed hunting.

fauna.identification: Brown in summer, white in winter. Large hind feet. Long ears. Fast runner.
fauna.educational_value: Small game species. Demonstrates seasonal adaptation.
fauna.conservation_notes: Snowshoe hare populations cycle naturally every 8-11 years. Currently stable.

fauna.identification: Reddish-orange fur, white chest and throat. Bushy tail with white tip. Dog-like appearance.
fauna.educational_value: Common predator. Some hunting/trapping. Ecological role in rodent control.
fauna.conservation_notes: Red fox populations stable. Adaptable to human presence.

fauna.identification: Grey-brown with black mask across eyes. Ringed bushy tail. Dexterous front paws.
fauna.educational_value: Highly adaptable. Common in urban and wild areas. Nocturnal.
fauna.conservation_notes: Raccoons highly adaptable. Common in urban and rural areas.

fauna.category: Game Species - Managed hunting, safety concern
fauna.identification: Large, all black or brown. Rounded ears, straight face profile. Powerful build.
fauna.educational_value: Game species and safety concern. Learn about bear safety and population control.
fauna.conservation_notes: Black bear populations healthy in Nova Scotia. Managed hunting seasons.

conservation_priorities.identification: Very small, about pinhead size. Eight legs. Black legs. Found in grass and brush.
conservation_priorities.educational_value: Can carry Lyme disease. Important for outdoor safety awareness.
conservation_priorities.conservation_notes: Tick populations expanding northward with climate change. Health concern.

conservation_priorities.identification: Green colored shell. Aggressive behavior. Five spines on each side of shell.
conservation_priorities.educational_value: Invasive species causing ecosystem damage. Learn about harmful introductions.
conservation_priorities.conservation_notes: Invasive species. Green crab itself is abundant but threatens native species.

conservation_priorities.identification: Grey-green with white belly. Three dorsal fins. Barbel on chin.
conservation_priorities.educational_value: Historically important fishery. Now protected due to overfishing.
conservation_priorities.conservation_notes: Atlantic cod populations collapsed in 1990s. Some recovery but still vulnerable.

conservation_priorities.identification: Silvery with black spots. Hooked jaw in breeding males. Powerful swimmer.
conservation_priorities.educational_value: Endangered. Demonstrates anadromous migration (freshwater to ocean and back).
conservation_priorities.iucn_status: Least Concern globally, but Endangered in parts of North America
conservation_priorities.conservation_notes: Inner Bay of Fundy Atlantic Salmon are endangered. Habitat loss and dams major threats.

conservation_priorities.identification: Large claws, dark greenish-brown color. Lives in rocky crevices.
conservation_priorities.educational_value: Major commercial fishery. Learn about sustainable management.
conservation_priorities.conservation_notes: Lobster fishery well-managed with size limits, season restrictions. Populations healthy.

conservation_priorities.identification: Snake-like fish with continuous fin. Dark on top, light below.
conservation_priorities.educational_value: Declining populations. Opposite migration of salmon (ocean to freshwater).
conservation_priorities.conservation_notes: Declined by 99% since 1980s. Dams, habitat loss, climate change.

conservation_priorities.category: Game Species - Managed hunting, safety concern
conservation_priorities.identification: Large, all black or brown. Rounded ears, straight face profile. Powerful build.
conservation_priorities.educational_value: Game species and safety concern. Learn about bear safety and population control.
conservation_priorities.conservation_notes: Black bear populations healthy in Nova Scotia. Managed hunting seasons.

game_species.identification: Black head and neck with white chinstrap. Brown body. V-formation flying. Loud honking.
game_species.educational_value: Major waterfowl hunting species. Teaches migration patterns.
game_species.conservation_notes: Canada goose populations have increased dramatically. Sometimes considered pest.

game_species.identification: Brown coat in summer, grey in winter. White tail flashes when running. Males have antlers. Look for tracks with split hooves.
game_species.educational_value: Primary game animal. Important for hunting regulations and wildlife management education.
game_species.conservation_notes: White-tailed deer abundant. Managed through hunting. Sometimes overabundant.

game_species.conservation_notes: Hunted but populations managed. Vehicle collisions a concern.

game_species.educational_value: Important game bird. Indicator of healthy forest habitat.
game_species.conservation_notes: Ruffed grouse populations stable. Managed hunting.

game_species.identification: Males have green head, yellow bill. Females brown mottled. Found on lakes and ponds.
game_species.educational_value: Important waterfowl hunting species. Wetland indicator.
game_species.conservation_notes: Mallard populations stable. Most common duck species.

game_species.identification: Brown in summer, white in winter. Large hind feet. Long ears. Fast runner.
game_species.educational_value: Small game species. Demonstrates seasonal adaptation.
game_species.conservation_notes: Snowshoe hare populations cycle naturally every 8-11 years. Currently stable.

game_species.identification: Dark with light spots and wavy markings. Red and blue spots. Orange fins.
game_species.educational_value: Native game fish. Indicator of cold, clean water.
game_species.conservation_notes: Native brook trout. Sensitive to water temperature and quality.

game_species.conservation_notes: Black bear populations healthy in Nova Scotia. Managed hunting seasons.

habitat_descriptions.saltwater: Ocean and tidal zone environments with high salt content
habitat_descriptions.freshwater: Lakes, rivers, and streams with no or low salt content
habitat_descriptions.terrestrial: Land-based environments including forests, fields, and wetlands
